title: ECOHAB: Van Dolah_F- Karenia brevis Cell Cycle Analysis for Determination of In Situ Growth Rates (NODC Accession 0000538)
name: ecohab-van-dolah-f-karenia-brevis-cell-cycle-analysis-for-determination-of-in-situ-growth-rates
notes: The reported growth rates of Karenia brevis vary from 0.2 ton0.5 divisions per day, both in laboratory and fieldnpopulations observed. This growth rate alone is notnsufficiently high to account for its dominance in the waterncolumn. However, careful studies have not been carried outnto determine if the documented slow growth rate of K. brevisnpersists throughout bloom development, or if different ratesnof growth might characterize bloom initiation, growth,nmaintenance, and termination phases. For example, it isnconceivable that an

growth stage occurs earlynduring bloom initiation/growth stages that serves to boostnthe population size, which has not been previouslyndocumented. Like most autotrophic dinoflagellates studied,ncell division in K. brevis blooms is phased to the dielncycle. Diel phasing of cell division imposes a maximumnpotential growth rate of 1 division per day inndinoflagellates. The occurrence of an

would require the release of K. brevis cells fromnmechanisms which regulate this circadian rhythm.nTo address this question, diel phasing of the cell cycle ofnK. brevis was first documented in laboratory isolates of K.nbrevis. In situ diel studies were then carried out onnnaturally occurring blooms of K. brevis during the R/VnPelican cruise (1996) and during ECOHAB process cruisesncarried out during years 1-5 of ECOHAB Florida (1997-2001).nCell cycle distribution of K. brevis cells and correlationnof cell cycle events with vertical migration was determinednby sampling at multiple depths (minimum of surface andnbottom, depending on depth). For shipboard field studies,nwhole water samples of K. brevis (1-2 L) were collectednevery 2 or 3 h throughout a diel cycle, fixed innglutaraldehyde and stored in the dark. Further processing ofnsamples was carried out in the laboratory followingncompletion of the cruise. The flow cytometry method methodnof Van Dolah and Leighfield was used (1999. J. Phycologyn35:1404-1411). Glutaraldehyde-fixed whole water samples werenfiltered through a 100 micrometer nitex screen to remove largenphytoplankton/zooplankton/debris, then filtered by gravitynflow through a 10 micrometer nylon screen to collect K. brevisncells. Cells were collected from the screen by rinsing withn2% glutaraldehyde into a 50 ml polypropylene centrifugentube, then centrifuged at 1000 x g. The cell pellet was thenntreated with 2 ml of 20 degrees C methanol overnight tonremove pigments. Methanol extracted cells were collected byncentrifugation (500xg for 3 min) and resuspended innphosphate buffered saline + 0.5% Tween 20 containing 10 micrograms.nmL-1 propidium iodide (PI, Sigma, St. Louis, MO) and 10nmg/ml Rnase (Sigma, St. Louis, MO). DNA analysis was carriednout on an Epics MXL4 flow cytometer (Coulter, Miami, FL)nusing a 5 W argon laser with a 488 nm excitation wavelengthnand 635 nm emission wavelength. Cell aggregates wereneliminated by gating all histograms within the linear rangenusing a peak-area cytogram for PI fluorescence. Cell cyclendistribution was analyzed using Multicycle software (PhoenixnFlow Systems, San Diego, CA).nnPurpose:nThe research conducted in this portion of the Florida ECOHABnProgram will provide insight into which the role ofnendogenous cellular rhythms in regulating the accumulationngrowth phase of K. brevis blooms decline by conducting cellncycle studies. This work entails both both laboratory andnfield experiments. Laboratory studies will be carried out tonidentify cell cycle regulatory mechanisms in K. brevis,nusing western blotting to identify cyclins and cyclinndependent kinases in K. brevis, and to determine theirnrelative levels of expression in actively growing versusnstationary phase K. brevis populations. In addition we willncharacterize their expression during the course of thencircadian day, as it correlates with cell cycle phase. Innsitu labeling of K. brevis cells with fluorescently labelednantibodies to cyclins will assist in discerning whetherncyclin expression might be suitable for use as a biomarkernof actively dividing blooms in the field. Field studies willnuse flow cytometry to determine in situ growth rates ofnblooms of K. brevis during the yearly ECOHAB process cruisesnin order to establish a multiyear record of growth rates innearly and late bloom stages.
